awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC:  Water and Environmental Technology Center
awd_abstract_narration:
In Phase II operation, the Water and Environmental Technology (WET) I/UCRC intends to minimize any adverse effects of emerging contaminants (EC) on human health and/or the environment. The research challenges in this area include the need for more scientific information about levels, fate, transport, ecological and health impacts of ECs in the environment, the need for improved detection and monitoring capabilities, and for new cost-effective treatment technologies and optimization of existing operations at both water and wastewater treatment plants.  Center engineers and environmental scientists utilizing microbial, chemical, and mathematic approaches will work collaboratively in coordination with center industry representatives to perform this research.  WET's industrial, need-focused research program aims to enhance scientific understanding and help address potentially significant health and environmental problems.


BROADER IMPACT
The challenges addressed and potential benefits derived from the work of the Water and Environmental Technology (WET) I/UCRC impact several industries including: the Pharmaceutical and Personal Care Products Industries; the Oil and Natural Gas Industry; Pesticide and other Chemicals Industry; entities that treat wastewater and drinking water; and companies that create and service technologies for the removal of contaminants from water.  Students and faculty will experience state of the art research projects of value to both industry and the community. Many member companies have overseas installations, and students will be exposed to regulatory, technological, social and cultural aspects of different countries, enhancing their global experiences. In addition, every effort will be made to engage and involve minority students, as well as students and teachers from local K-12 schools, in part through existing programs at the center's institutions.  The Center will further enhance the ongoing efforts at the three institutions of integrating research into classroom teaching.

por.por_cntn:
The Water and Environmental Technology Center, or the WET Center, was a National Science Foundation Industry-University Cooperative Research Center. The WET Center had three academic institution partners: Temple University (Lead), Arizona State University, and the University of Arizona. The mission of the WET Center was to research and develop optimal water treatment technologies and methods to mitigate the adverse impacts of water scarcity and contamination on human health and the environment. A core value of the Center is that all water is valuable regardless of its source, and can be treated to any required water quality standard based on its intended use. Because many source waters contain contaminants such as industrial chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and microbial pathogens, the Center evaluates and develops new technologies and analytical methods to treat and improve water quality for the benefit of people and the environment.

Our industrial revolution has, unfortunately, resulted in chemicals being released into the environment. Diminishing water sources are pushing water utilities and water suppliers to increasingly rely on water resources with inferior water quality. A key technical challenge undertaken by the Center is to understand and eliminate the many types of contaminants that may be present in such waters. Current examples of these contaminants include per- and polyfluorinated substances (PFAS), microplastics, and antimicrobial resistant genes (ARGs). The research at the Center is guided by a technology roadmap developed by the members of its Industrial Advisory Board. The IAB consists of companies and public utilities with interests and missions in water quality and treatment. Center projects included areas such as: Non-Traditional Water Sources; Natural Treatment Systems; Risk Assessment and Life Cycle Analysis; Analytical Technologies; Emerging Contaminants of Concern (ECC) Fate, Effects and Treatment Technologies; Environmental Fate of Microplastics; Municipal Water Use Practices and Wastewater Reuse. In water scarce areas, technologies that focus on the water/energy nexus become even more important. Working collaboratively with public and private sector personnel, Center engineers and environmental scientists use real-world management approaches and innovative technologies to solve the most pressing water use challenges.

Another objective of the Center is to develop a cadre of engineers and scientists that can play an important role in society in providing water suitable for its intended use in sufficient quantities, i.e. water security. The Center and its research activity involved faculty researchers, providing research training to 35+ graduate and undergraduate students and 12 postdoctoral researchers. The Center researchers shared their research outcomes at professional meetings and conferences (60+) and published 40+ papers in peer reviewed journals.  A list of predicted no-effect concentration (PNEC) of pharmaceutical chemicals in water was created and is available on Center website. The Temple WET Center will continue its operations independent of NSF, and more information can be found at nsfwetcenter.org.  

A large number of projects were successfully completed and below are just a few examples:

  1. A novel polymer coated sand adsorbent was developed at Temple for the removal of PFAS from water. The adsorbent is regenerable and reusable, thereby offering a very cost efficient and environmentally sustainable solution to industry. The technology has been granted 2 U.S. patents. PFAS have recently gained media, public, and regulatory attention world-wide. They have been detected in environment and human blood. At high concentrations, certain PFAS have been linked to adverse health effects such as low birth weight, delayed puberty onset, elevated cholesterol levels, and reduced immunologic responses to vaccination. The USEPA issued a drinking water lifetime health advisory of 70 parts per trillion (ppt) for PFOA and PFOS (combined). Some state regulatory agencies have issued their own regulations or guidelines. The Center also researched an ion-exchange (IX) technology for the removal of PFAS from water. As a result, one of the Center?s IAB members used Center research results to develop a commercial product using IX for PFAS treatment. The IX product has been implemented at a number of sites for purification of groundwater and drinking water. Center research and the resulting commercialization are providing cost-effective solutions to address the widespread PFAS contamination issue.
  2. Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) and Life Cycle Costing (LCC) of water purification technologies for the removal of ECCs: The results of this research could assist industries in the selection of environmentally sustainable and overall cost-effective technologies for their treatment operations.
  3. Development of ECC degradation predictive methods using quantum chemistry calculations, quantitative structure-activity and structure-property relationships: The developed theoretical approach significantly reduced the cost and time of labor-intensive lab research and sample analysis. This approach provides a first step screening tool to define the degradability of ECCs and the technical feasibility of purification technologies. 
  4. Chemical Markers of Human Waste in Watersheds: This research provided information on sources of human waste pollution in watershed. The project created a unique ?fingerprint? or ?signature? that can be used as an indicator of human sewage contamination.
